name: Okta Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
title: Okta Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
body:
In this article, you will learn how to integrate Okta with SecurityCoach. Once you set up this integration, data provided by Okta will be available under the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console. This data can be viewed in SecurityCoach reports and used to create detection rules for real-time coaching campaigns.

For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Tip:SecurityCoach also supports integrating Okta as a Splunk vendor. If your organization uses Splunk for security information and event management, we recommend integrating through Splunk instead by following our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.

Create Your Okta API Token

Before you can set up this integration in your KSAT console, you will need to create a read-only administrator account. Then, you will need to create an API token using this new account.

To jump to the article subsection for each of these steps, click the links below:

  • Create a Read-Only Administrator Account
  • Create Your API Token

Create a Read-Only Administrator Account

First, you will need to create a read-only administrator account for Okta. To create the account, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Okta console.
  2. Navigate to Directory > People.
  3. Click Add person.
  4. In the Add Person pop-up window that opens, enter the details for the new user.
  5. Click Save to create the new user.
  6. Navigate to Security > Administrators.
  7. Click + Add administrator.
  8. Fill out the fields on the Administrator assignment by admin page. For more information about these fields, see below:
    1. Admin: Select the user you created in step 5 above.
    2. Role: Select Read-only Administrator.
  9. Click Save Changes to create the new administrator account.

Create Your API Token

After you have created a read-only administrator account, you can create your API token.

To create your API token, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Okta console with the read-only administrator account you created in the Create a Read-Only Administrator Account section above.
  2. Navigate to Security > API.

  3. Select the Tokens tab.
  4. Click Create Token.

  5. Enter a name for the token.

  6. Click Create Token. Once you click this button, your token will display.
    Important:Make sure to copy this token and save it in a place that you can easily access later. You will need this token during the setup process in the Set Up the Integration in KSAT section below.
  7. Once you have saved your token, click the OK, got it button to close the window.

Once you have your API token, you can continue the setup process in your KSAT console.

Set Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console

Once you've created your Okta API token, you can set up the integration in your KSAT console. To set up the integration in your KSAT console, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup.

  2. In the Available Integrations section, locate the Okta card and click Configure.

  3. Paste your API token in the API Token field. This is the API token that you created in the Create Your API Token section above.

  4. In the API Domain field, enter your organization's unique Okta domain.
    Note: If you do not know your Okta domain, you can locate it by following the steps in Okta's Find your Okta Domain article. If you need to access your Okta account to locate your domain, please open a separate window to log in to your Okta account.
  5. Click Authorize.

Map Your Users

After you’ve finished integrating Okta, you can map your users either through mapping rules (recommended) or through a CSV file upload. For more information about user mapping, see our Mapping Users in SecurityCoach article.

Once you’ve successfully authorized this integration, you can manage detection rules for Okta on the Detection Rules subtab of SecurityCoach. For a full list of available system detection rules for this vendor, see our Which Detection Rules Can I Use with My Vendors? article.

images.alt:
This image captures the Okta administrative interface, displaying a navigation sidebar and a main content area.

**Header and Main Content:**
*   The top left features the **"okta"** logo.
*   The top right includes a search bar labeled **"Search..."** with a magnifying glass icon.
*   The main content area is titled **"Get started with Okta"**.
*   Subtext reads: "For more topics, see **all developer documentation**."
*   A section titled **"Tell Us About Yourself"** is visible, with a subsection titled **"Customize your goals"**.
*   Placeholder UI elements (gray rectangles with green checkmark circles) suggest a completion or task list, with an action link **"Customize"** visible on the right.

**Navigation Sidebar (Left Panel):**
The sidebar shows hierarchical menu items.
*   Top-level items include: **Customizations**, **Applications**, **Security**, **Workflow**, and **Reports**.
*   The **"Security"** item is highlighted by an orange rectangular border, indicating selection, and is expanded (showing an upward-pointing chevron).
*   The expanded sub-menu items under **"Security"** are listed:
    *   General
    *   HealthInsight
    *   Authentication
    *   Multifactor
    *   Identity Providers
    *   Delegated Authentication
    *   Networks
    *   Behavior Detection
    *   Administrators
    *   **API** (An orange arrow explicitly points to this item).

This image displays a segment of an administrative interface for API management, specifically centered on token configuration.

**Context and Navigation:**
*   The primary page header is **API**, preceded by a lock icon. A **Help** link is positioned in the top right.
*   Horizontal tab navigation is visible, listing **Authorization Servers**, **Tokens**, and **Trusted Origins**. The **Tokens** tab is currently active, indicated by a blue underline.

**Action Elements:**
*   A blue primary button, emphasized with a key/wrench icon, is labeled **Create Token**.

**Search and Filtering Controls:**
*   Below the main action button, a search bar is presented.
    *   An input field includes the placeholder text: **Token value**.
    *   A button labeled **Find Token** is used to execute the search.
*   On the right, a sorting/filtering control is displayed, prefaced by the label **Search by**. The active selection in the blue dropdown menu is **Last used: Most recent** (indicated by a downward chevron).

A modal dialog window, titled "**Create Token**," overlays a partially visible background interface.

**Content:**

1.  **Title:** "Create Token" (large, bold text).
2.  **Close Button:** An "X" icon in the top right corner.
3.  **Prompt:** "What do you want your token to be named?"
4.  **Input Field:** A text input box, currently focused (indicated by a blue/purple outline and an active cursor). The input contains the pre-filled or entered value: "testtoken".
5.  **Context Text:** Below the input field, gray text reads: "The token name is used for tracking API calls."

**Action Buttons (Bottom Right):**

1.  **Primary Action:** A solid blue button labeled "**Create Token**".
2.  **Secondary Action:** A hyperlink-style button labeled "**Cancel**".

images.alt:
This image displays a modal dialog box titled "**Create Token**" following a successful operation.

**Header and Status:**
*   The title is "**Create Token**."
*   A success message is displayed in green text: "**Token created successfully!**"
*   A contextual warning/instruction follows: "Please make a note of this token as it will be the only time that you will be able to view it. After this, it will be stored as a hash for your protection."

**Token Display Area:**
*   A label reads "**Token Value**."
*   Below the label is an input field containing the generated token (blurred for security/privacy).
*   An adjacent button displays a clipboard icon, providing a "**Copy**" function for the token value.

**Action Button:**
*   The only visible primary action button is labeled "**OK, got it**" (rendered in blue with a subtle orange border highlight).
*   A standard 'X' icon is present in the top right corner, likely serving as a close/dismiss function.

**Context:**
The dialog serves to present a newly generated, sensitive access token that is only visible at the moment of creation, emphasizing the need for immediate user capture.
images.context: r token, click the OK, got it button to close the window.

images.alt:
This image displays a segment of the KnowBe4 user interface (UI).

**Primary Navigation (Header Bar):**
The top menu bar lists primary modules, with **SECURITYCOACH** highlighted in blue, indicating it is the currently active module. Other visible modules include DASHBOARD, PHISHING, TRAINING, VISHING, USB, USERS, ASAP, SECOND CHANCE, MODSTORE, and REPORTS.

**Content Area:**
The main content section is titled **Integrations** (bold, large font).

**Secondary Navigation (Contextual Menu):**
A contextual sub-navigation menu related to the **Integrations** section is visible, containing the following links: Dashboard, Real-Time Coaching, Detection Rules, Catalog, **Setup**, and Reports.

**Focal Element:**
The **Setup** tab within the secondary navigation is visually styled as the currently selected item (light gray background). A large, superimposed orange arrow points directly downward, specifically highlighting the **Setup** navigation element.
images.context: e and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup.

images.alt:
The image displays a standardized User Interface card featuring the following elements:

1.  **Branding:** The dark blue, lowercase **okta** logotype is centrally positioned within the container.
2.  **Action Button:** A full-width, solid blue primary action button is located at the bottom.
3.  **Button Text:** The button contains centered white text labeled **Configure**.

This UI element represents an initial setup or integration prompt for the Okta identity platform.
images.context: ate the Okta card and click Configure.

images.alt:
This image displays a User Interface screen for configuring a vendor integration, specifically labeled **Okta**.

**Header and Navigation:**
*   The page title is **Okta**.
*   A link in the top right, labeled **← Back to Integrations**, allows the user to exit the current configuration screen.

**Instructional Banner:**
*   A light-blue instructional banner is present, stating: "For more information about configuring this vendor integration, click **Configuration Help**."
*   A prominent button labeled **Configuration Help** is positioned within this banner, likely leading to documentation.

**Input Fields:**
*   Two required text input fields are displayed side-by-side:
    1.  **API Token** (This field is visually highlighted by an orange border, indicating required input or current focus).
    2.  **API Domain**

**Action Buttons:**
*   Below the input fields, two control buttons are present:
    1.  **Reset** (Standard, secondary button).
    2.  **Authorize** (Primary, blue-filled button, intended to validate and save the entered API Token and API Domain).

This image displays a configuration screen titled "Okta User Mapping."

**Header and Context:**
The page title is "Okta User Mapping."
The introductory paragraph explains: "Map your users by either configuring your mapping rules or uploading a CSV file below. Mapping your users to identifiers links events from this endpoint vendor to specific users. For more information about user mapping, see our **Mapping Users in SecurityCoach** article." ("Mapping Users in SecurityCoach" is a hyperlink).

**Navigation Tabs:**
Two primary configuration methods are presented via tabs:
1. **Mapping Rules (Recommended)** (Active tab, highlighted)
2. **CSV File Upload** (Inactive tab, text link)

**Active Configuration Pane ("Configure Mapping Rules"):**
The active pane is titled "Configure Mapping Rules" and includes the description: "Configure your mapping rules to map your users to KMSAT user data fields. This is the recommended method for mapping your users."

**Rule Configuration Element (Default Rule):**
A single mapping rule is shown, structured as an inline sentence:
*   `Okta` (Static text)
*   `Hostname` (Field displayed in a gray background box, representing an Okta field)
*   `is` (Static text)
*   **Knowbe4 User Data Field** (Above a dropdown input field)
*   Dropdown input field with placeholder "Select option"
*   Button: "Add Field" (Outline button)

**Rule Management Options:**
*   Link: "Add Another Rule" (Below the default rule)

**Action Buttons (Footer):**
At the bottom of the screen, two action buttons are present:
*   **Save** (Primary button, blue background)
*   **Delete Integration** (Secondary button, red outline)
